title: effects of flow variation on channel and floodplain biota and habitats of the sacramento river, california, usa
predictors: daily mean flow, water velocity, residence time, simulated flooded surface area, temperature
responses: Chlorophyll a, crustacean zooplankton community, drift invertebrates
chlorophyll_method: Chlorophyll a was measured as an indicator of phytoplankton biomass in discrete water samples collected weekly
food_web: Copepods and cladoceran densities were similar in the river and its floodplain, and were mostly negatively associated with flow, There were significantly higher densities of Diptera and terrestrial invertebrates in the floodplain than the river. Diptera densities in the floodplain were positively associated with flow
data_analysis_method: Sign testes and Pearson correlation coefficients for log-transformed data
notes: NA
temporal_def: months in plots but vague about 'seasonality'
connectivity_def: Flooding of the Yolo Bypass began when flow in the adjacent Sacramento River exceeded about 1500m3 s–1
cc_notes: site and event (based on water-level) - river (Sacramento River) and its seasonal floodplain (Yolo Bypass), Feb-May 1998, 2000, 2001
p_value: Chlorophyll a levels were significantly higher in the floodplain than in the river, and were negatively associated with flow. These results were consistent with longer hydraulic residence times, increased surface area of shallow water, and warmer water temperatures

title: hydrologic controls on the trophic status of shallow lakes on the boreal plain
notes: NA

title: hydrologic variability, water chemistry, and phytoplankton biomass in a large floodplain of the sacramento river, ca, u.s.a
responses:
Specific conductance (tiS cm- 1 ), dissolved inorganic
specific conudncatnce, disoolved silica, nitrate, nitrite, ammonium, dissolved reactive phosphate, sulfate , sodium, chlorophyll a, and seston C:N ratio in the
Sacramento River at Fremont Weir during the inundation period
chlorophyll_method: water samples, Chlorophyll a was extracted with methanol and measured using a Turner Designs Model 10 AU fluorometer
notes: conceptual model we could use, other water chemistry-connecitivity results
p_value: Concentrations of chlorophyll a in the Yolo Bypass increased briefly in early February, when local streams were discharging to the floodplain, but then decreased and remained low ( <4 11 g 1- 1) until the end of the inundation period. Chlorophyll a had increased at all three Yolo Bypass sites (6-9 J-tg ;- 1) by March 17, the end of the inundation period.Chlorophyll a remained high at all three Yolo Bypass sites and in Ridge Cut through mid-April, and then decreased at the Lower Bypass site after the small storm in late April.

title: Hydrological seasonality and benthic algal biomass in a Neotropical floodplain river
site_size: lowland tributary on the Orinoco River, ~12 km stretch
connectivity_metric: water-level threshold that discriminated the 2 hydrological periods was 290 to 320 cm
predictors: flow (mechanical flow meter), temperature, dissolved O2 (YSI 95 O2 meter), transparency (Secchi disk), conductivity, pH
responses: flow (mechanical flow meter), temperature, dissolved O2 (YSI 95 O2 meter), transparency (Secchi disk), conductivity, pH, NH4, NO3, NO2, urea, soluble reactive P (SRP), and SiO3 concentrations, sediment core samples to examine B-CHLA (chlorophyll a corrected for phaeophytin a) and B-PHAE
chlorophyll_method: A Petri dish was pushed into the substrate, and a spatula was placed under the Petri dish to trap the contents during retrieval. The filters and Petri dishes were kept frozen and stored in the dark until analyses were performed. S-CHLA, S-PHAE, B-CHLA, and B-PHAE were determined using the overnight 90% acetone extraction protocol using spectrofluorometric and spectrophotometric methods
notes: results were variable, descriptive study, but relevant theme, chl was higher with less connecitivty (for a system that was always connected), so seemed to be related to higher water residence time
temporal_def: low water: Jan-Apr 2002, Feb-Apr 2003, high water: May & Dec 2002, May-Jul 2003
connectivity_def: water flow in the floodplain lakes and submergence of point sandbars in the main channel
cc_notes: 2 hydrological periods with sites in river and lagoon sites (in floodplain lakes that were continuously connected with the main channel), monthly, Jan-May 2002 and Dec-Jul 2003 (wet season is from May to November)
p_value: S-CHLAwas inversely correlated with the water level, B-CHLA was highest in the floodplain lakes

title: patterns of fish communities and water quality in impounded lakes of china's south-to-north water diversion project
watershed: Yangtze River, Huai River, YellowRiver and Haihe River
water_body_type: transfer canal (54 pumping station), chain of lakes
site_size:
From south to
north, the five impounded lakes of the eastern route of the SNWDP are Gaoyou Lake (GYL), Hongze Lake (HZL), Luoma Lake (LML), Nansi
Lake (NSL) and Dongping Lake (DPL), with a distance of about 146, 301, 427, 622, and 764km respectively fromthe start of thewater diversion
responses: Water temperature, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH, Water depth, transparency, chloride, total hardness, TP, PO4, TN, NH4N, NO3N, NO2N, chlorophyll a, suspendeid solids, chemical oxygen demand
food_web: fish communities (i.e., pelagic and benthic multi-mesh gillnets and ground cages)
notes: showed high similarities of fish communities among impounded lakes has promoted connections between previously isolated or partially connected catchments and may have accelerated the remix of fish communities from different catchments.
cc_notes: distance from diversion/water transfer canal (54 pumping station) along a chain of lakes, Apr-May 2017
p_value: The two lakes closer to the source of the diversion system were five to ten times more turbid, had three times more total suspended solids, and twice as much chlorophyll a as the lakes further away

title: water samples
water_body_type: river, upsteam, between and downstream of reservoirs
connectivity_metric: degree of connection between consecutive neighboring sites (river network analysis)
predictors: water temperature, conductivity,water flow and nutrients, dissolved inorganic nitrogen, soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP), Dissolved Inorganic Carbon, Dissolved Organic Carbon  and Dissolved Organic Nitrogen
responses: phytoplankton biomass (biovolume and chlorophyll-a concentration), community structure
notes: Both the overall river as well as the separated two river segments showed that neighbors' effect on the chlorophyll-a was positive, that is, that values in each river sites were influenced by upstream ones. However, that influence of neighbor sites decreases considerably downstream of the dams, leading to individuality. Planktonic chlorophyll-a correlated differently with environmental variables in upstream or downstream sections
connectivity_def: spatial distribution of the biological and environmental variables, separating the variability in the river sections upstream and downstream the reservoirs (site means)- Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) Moran Index Correlation lengths, Quantification of local vs extra-local influences
cc_notes: site (upsteam/downstream), spatial distribution of the biological and environmental variables, separating the variability in the river sections upstream and downstream the reservoirs (including degree of connection between consecutive neighboring sites (e.g., river network analysis, spatial autocorrelation indicators - Moran index)), 2008-2013 (seaonality is unclear, 18 "campaigns" from different hydrological conditions, but results presented by site only)
include_exclude_reason: was difficult to address connectivity, because they tested fragmentation
p_value: diversity even increased downstream of the reservoirs; the substantial loss of biomass contrasted to the increase of species diversity

title: suspended sediment, nutrients, and chlorophyll in tropical floodplain lakes with different patterns of hydrological connectivity
site_size: San Pedrito (1360.2 ha), La Puerta-Pajaral (178 ha) and San Isidro (139 ha) lakes, lengths of the San Pedrito and San Isidro channels are 2.5 and 8.5 km, respectively. Lakes Canitzán (510.1 ha) and Nueva Esperanza (400 ha)
seasons: March and December, low water (March-April), rainy season (June-October) and “nortes” (December)
responses: Secchi depth, water temperature, conductivity, dissolved oxygen (concentration and saturation), and pHnitrate (cadmium reduction method), soluble reactive phosphorus (ascorbic acid method), and total phosphorus (persulphate digestion). Total suspended solids, inorganic suspended solids, and percent organic matter, as the proportion of organic suspended matter of TSS, Chlorophyll a
chlorophyll_method: Van Dorn water sampler, hot ethanol extraction
notes: lots of detail on connecitivty: The study lakes showed contrasting patterns in connectivity from permanent connection in the Centla lakes to a short connection phase in the TEZ lakes. In contrast, floodplain lakes in rivers with unimodal discharge patterns such as the Amazon and the Orinoco, exhibit a clear isolation and inundation phases, that can last several months; however, in some large lakes, connection with the main channel can be permanent through small channels or flooded forest
temporal_def: dry season from February through May and a rainy season from June through October associated with the intertropical convergence zone (lower flows in April-May and higher flows in October –November)
connectivity_def: flood that occurred in late November 2015 (two weeks)
cc_notes: lakes permanently connected to the river and in lakes that only received water from the Usumacinta for a short period during peak flow, Mar-Sept 2015 (low water, rainy, â€œnortesâ€)
p_value: Chlorophyll a concentrations were higher in the connected lakes than in the river only during the dry season, while the more isolated lakes exhibited higher values through the year, showing signs of eutrophication (p-values).

title: towards deconfounding hydrological and seasonal temperature variability in the determination of selected limnological variables of a temperate floodplain ecosystem
seasons: monthly from summer (July) 2002 to summer (May) 2008, and were not collected during the winters because the study area was frozen
connectivity_metric: three hydrological phases (isolation, flow pulse and flood pulse) and according to three seasons (spring, summer and autumn)
responses: pH, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, nitrites, nitrates, ammonium, total Kjeldahl nitrogen, total phosphorus, chlorophyll a concentrations and ratio of copiotrophic to oligotrophic bacteria
data_analysis_method: permutational multivariate analysis of variance, Canonical Analysis of Principal Coordinates (CAP)
notes: intersting take: "hydrological connectivity is a confounding variable when investigating the impact of seasonal temperature change on dependent variables, and vice versa; seasonal temperature change is a confounding variable when investigating impact of hydrology on dependent variables."
temporal_def: spring: 21 March to 21 June; summer: 21 June to 23 September; autumn: 23 September to 21 December
connectivity_def: isolation (Danube water level <1·67m at Apatin gauge; lentic conditions), 2, flow pulse (>1·67; semilotic or lotic conditions), and 3, flood pulse (>3m; lotic conditions)
cc_notes: resutls presented by three hydrological phases (isolation (Danube water level <1Â·67m), flow pulse (>1Â·67m) and flood pulse(>3m) and three seasons (spring, summer and autumn), sampled monthly, from July 2002 to May 2008, except during the winters because the study area was frozen
p_value: Interannual variability in the Chl a concentration and Co:Ol ratio was pronounced and significantly inversely related to the River Danube water level (r (Chl a) =0·53 (caveat: interaction between flow and seaon - lowest flows in warmest season...)

title: bacterioplankton from two hungarian danube river wetlands (beda-karapancsa, danube-drava national park) and its relations to environmental variables
site_size: floodplain sidearm (3.4 km long, 60 m wide) and oxbow (4.5 km long and 80 m wide)
responses: TOC (total organic carbon), DOC (dissolved organic carbon) and TN (total nitrogen), suspended solids, NO3-N, NH4-N, PO4-P, TP (total phosphorus), and Chl-a (chlorophyll-a)
primary_productivity_metric: number of bacteria, biomass (in carbon content), biovolumes of cells of different morphological groups, number of detritus particles with attached bacteria
data_analysis_method: Redundancy Analysis, one-way ANOVA, nonparametric correlations of Spearman, linear regression
notes: very short and incomplete, chl-a is measured, but the study is about bacteria
connectivity_def: site (sidearm more connected than oxbow lake)
cc_notes: site with water-level (floodplain sidearm more connected than oxbow lake), April-May, July-August and September-October, 2014
include_exclude_reason: no relationship between primary productivity and connectivity
p_value: The seasonal and spatial development of bacterioplankton and its relation to DOC, PO4-P, TP, NO3-N, NH4-N and chl-a suggest that bacterioplankton actively participates in the decomposition of the dead organic matter and self-purification of water and in remineralisation of nutrients to be used by primary producers (phytoplankton and macrophytes) in the wetlands. The lower bacterioplankton number in summer and autumn is probably connected with the increase of zooplankton pressure and competition with macrophytes and phytoplankton for nutrients.

title: development, maintenance and role of riparian vegetation in the river landscape
notes: na

title: hydrological connectivity drives patterns of macroinvertebrate biodiversity in floodplain rivers of the australian wet /dry tropics
watershed: ‘tropical’ Gregory River, Beanes Brook and ‘dryland’ Flinders, Cloncurry River
water_body_size: Nicholson (52 300 km2) and Flinders (109 400 km2) catchments
connectivity_process: the lotic or lentic status of waterbodies
connectivity_metric: catchment, river section, lateral position, flow status
predictors:
hydro-geomorphological and biophysical measures - waterbody (seven variables), within-waterbody (eight variables) and macroinvertebrate habitat (12 variables), Conductivity, salinity and pH, Dissolved oxygen, Light irradiance, Light attenuation, chlorophyll-a, total and dissolved nitrogen and phosphorus, nnd organic and inorganic fractions of suspended
solids
chlorophyll_method: three replicate samples each of littoral zone sediment and biofilm
primary_productivity_metric: ChlS, median biomass chlorophyll-a in littoral-zone sediment (g m2); ChlB, median biomass of chlorophyll-a in littoral-zone biofilm (g m2); reported in a table
data_analysis_method: taxinomic composition, functional composition and diversity (richness, abuncance, Margalef's index, Berger-Parker index, beta-diversity), ANOSIM, NMDS, correlation, ANOVA
notes: NA
connectivity_def: Waterbodies were classified as either lotic or lentic, representing their hydrological connection or disconnection at the time of sampling
cc_notes: Waterbodies were classified as either lotic or lentic, representing their hydrological connection or disconnection at the time of sampling (dry season only (May-Oct) sampling in 2005 and 2006)
include_exclude_reason: no relationship between primary productivity and connectivity
p_value: not reported in relation to connectivity, functional macroinvertebrate composition was explained by areal amount of chlorophyll-a (among other things)

title: nitrogen subsidies from hillslope alder stands to streamside wetlands and headwater streams, kenai peninsula, alaska
watershed: Kenai lowlands (Ninilchik River, Deep Creek, Stariski Creek, and the Anchor River)
connectivity_process: flow path (10 m resolution digital elevation models)
connectivity_metric: alder-near, alder-far (distance along a flow path)
predictors: water level, alder distance to stream, hydraulic conductivity, groundwater velocity, fertilizer/no fertilizer
responses: Nitrate-N concentrations in groundwater (mg/L), C. canadensis biomass
primary_productivity_metric: soil, foliage and aerial shoots samples - stable nitrogen isotopic composition and C. canadensis biomass
notes: Means (SE) for the Nitrogen Content (%N), Biomass (g/m2) of Calamagrostis canadensis, Biomass (g/m2) of Other Species, and the Percentage of Total Biomass that Was C. canadensis in Control and Fertilized Streamside Wetlands at the Alder-Near, Alder-Far, No-Alder
connectivity_def: flow paths between alder stands and headwater streams (alder-near (i.e., flow path length <80 m) and alder-far (i.e., flow path length >80 m)
cc_notes: flow path (10 m resolution digital elevation models) used to create categories (alder-near (i.e., flow path length <80 m) and alder-far (i.e., flow path length >80 m), jun/jul 2011
include_exclude_reason: include only if Nitrogen Content and plant biomass
p_value: groundwater nitrate-N concentrations were significantly higher at alder-near sites than at no-alder sites, but did not differ significantly between alder-far sites and no-alder sites or between alder-far sites and alder-near sites

title: patterns of primary and heterotrophic productivity in an arid lowland river
predictors: depth, underwater light profiles, average wetted perimeter, areas of macrophyte bed, macrophyte biomass, variation in tree canopy, "componeent" (open water, phytoplankton, benthic algae, course woody debris, detritus), site
responses: gross primary production (gC m-2 y-1), community respiration, net organic matter, standing stock
chlorophyll_method: extracting GF/C filtered samples into boiling 90% ethanol and reading absorbonce spectrophotometrically
primary_productivity_metric: System metabolism (within each river reach was estimated from diel changes in the dissolved oxygen concentration measured using Clarke-type oxygen sensors fitted to submersible monitoring units), phytoplankton metabolism (Single opaque bottles were incubated at three depths to estimate planktonic respiration rates), chl-a concentration, gross primary production (gC m-2 y-1), community respiration, net organic matter, standing stock
notes: lots of bar charts (gross primary production, community respiration, net organic matter, standing stock)
cc_notes: connectivity themes in introduction only, september (spring) + 15 months
include_exclude_reason: no relationship between primary productivity and connectivity
p_value: chl-a mentioned in methods, but no results shown (only used to calculate bimass?)

title: persistence of clear-water, shallow-lake ecosystems: the role of protected areas and stable aquatic food webs
responses: turbidity, surface water samples (total nitrogen, total phosphorus, chlorophyll a), zooplankton, submerged aquatic macrophytes (C and N), sediment cores(% calcium carbinate), and fish (calcium carbonate flux, organic flux, mineral flux, TP, C:N, radiometric dating of the sediment core, sediment metal concentrations)
primary_productivity_metric: chlorophyll a, percent macrophyte coverage of submerged and floating vegetation, C:N and TP of modern aquatic and terrestrial vegetation and the sediment cores, sub-fossil diatom assemblages
food_web: zooplankton and fish (mentioned in methods, but no results shown)
notes:
that lack of hydrologic connectivity
and isolated, small catchments are important
factors in the promotion of clear-water shallow lake
ecosystems, mainly because they prevent colonization
by fish and associated ecological consequences
cc_notes: isolated lake, July (peak of growing season), 1996-2010
include_exclude_reason: not about connecitivity (lack of connecitivty mentioned in abstract vaguely applies to study)

title: reach-scale river metabolism across contrasting sub-catchment geologies; effect of light and hydrology
watershed: River Avon sub-catchments - rivers Wylye, Nadder, and Sem
connectivity_metric: ratio between base flow and stream discharge over 9 day period
responses:
O2 concentration, Bottom drag coef?cient, Conductivity-temperature-depth, Compensation irradiance, Light saturation parameter, Ecosystem respiration, AEC-based turbulent oxygen ?ux , Gross primary production
AEC measurement height, Net ecosystem metabolism, Net ecosystem primary production Dissolved oxygen, Production, Photosynthesis–irradiance Photosynthetically active radiation Maximum production rate, Respiration
primary_productivity_metric: respiration rates - Gross primary production (in mmol O2 m-2 d-1), Net ecosystem primary production - O2, light response, stream metabolism
notes: use O2 or net ecosystem metabolism as productivity measure (mean and SD reported for O2, plot for NEM), related to season and site but connectivity response is unclear
connectivity_def: stream discahre over cross-section flow transects at upstream and downstream ends of site each season
cc_notes: cross-section flow transects at upstream and downstream ends of site each season, ratio between base flow and stream discharge over 9-day periodÂ (represents the average period of hydrological imprint for carbon turnover within the reaches), apr 2013-feb 2014
include_exclude_reason: include only if O2 is used in other studies
p_value: Sub-catchment speci?c net ecosystem metabolism proved to be positively related to the local hydrological connectivity, quanti?ed as the ratio between base ?ow and stream discharge, and expressed on a timescale of 9 d on average

title: fish assemblages of tropical floodplain lagoons: exploring the role of connectivity in a dry year
predictors: connectivity, water temperature, depth, turbidity, pH, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, total nitrogen, total phosphorus, chlorophyll a, zooplankton density
responses: fish species richness, density, and biomass; dissolved oxygen, total nitrogen, total phosphorus, chlorophyll a, zooplankton density
chlorophyll_method: unclear (provided by the Limnology and Zooplankton Laboratories of Nupelia, not collected by authors, so methods not included)
notes: NA
connectivity_def: disconnected defined as isolated from the main river since March 1999 through study eriod; connected defined as permanently linke to the main river by channels. Connecting channels varried in length and size
cc_notes: connected and disconnected lagoons sampled in feb, may, august, and nov. Connected lagoons were permenently link to main river. Disconnected lagoons were isolated throughout the stud period. Connectivity was not defined by distance, but authors discussed general differences in distance between different groups (i.e. "disconnected lagoons were generally more distant from the main river channel (10-500m).

title: hydrological connectivity as most probable key driver of chlorophyll and nutrients in oxbow lakes of the bug river (poland)
site_size: see table 1 for surface area of each lake
responses: water quality parameters: conductivity, pH, suspended solids, chlorophyll a, ammonium-nitorgen, nitrate-nitrogen, phosphorus,
data_analysis_method: linear discriminant analysis, canonical analysis, ANOVA
notes: chlorophyll a was assumed to be equibalent to phytoplankton biomass
connectivity_def: connected defined as connected with the river channel and isolated from other water inputs, connected+ defined as connected to both river and other water inputs from the catchment, isolated defined as completely isolated from the river
cc_notes: oxbow lakes of connected, connected+, or isolated status were sampled in spring and summer of one year
include_exclude_reason: includes mean, sd, and n of relevant water quality parameters including chl-a

title: influence of hydrological heterogeneity on rotifer community structure in three different water bodies in shantou area, guangdong (china)

title: rotifer abundance, biomass, and secondary production after the recovery of hydrologic connectivity between a river and two marginal lakes (sao paulo, brazil)
water_body_size: Coqueiral Lake surface area is 641,263 square meters; Camargo Lake surface area is 224,465 square meters; volume and depth for each also included
predictors: water temperature, transparency, dissolved oxygen, pH, alkalinity, electrical conductivity, suspended and organic particulate matter, chlorophyll a, total nitrogen, total phosphorus, ammonium, nitrate, nitrite, dissolved total and inorganic phosphate
responses: integrated zooplankton samples, rotifer species, biomass
notes: has chlorophyll data measured at different states of connectivity, but does not seem to include SD or data tables
cc_notes: two lakes near river; generally are permenantly connected to river, but sampling occurred at the end of a drought during which with lakes had been disconnected. Sampling occurred during the time that connectivity was reestablished (Jan), and then in the dry season during "hydrologic stability" (July)

title: spatial distribution of nutrient limitation in the danube river floodplain in relation to hydrological connectivity
responses: water temperature, depth, Secchi depth, pH, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, ammonium, nitrate, nitrite, Kjeldahl nigrogen, total nitrogen, orthophosphate, total phosphorus, chl-a, chl-b, chl-c, algal growth potential
notes: need to clarify how connectivity maps to the 5 habitat type designations
temporal_def: ascending water level, stagnating water level, descending water level
cc_notes: some sites along river channel, some in lateral dimension, "based on hydrological connectivity among the chose sites and the river, we have distinguished five types of aquatic habitats along the flooding gradient". But definitions are not provided.

title: the impact of inundation-isolation cycles on the culturable bacterioplankton in the danube river floodplain
watershed: Danube River, Kopacki Rit Nature Park
predictors: innundation pattern/connectivity, water dpeth, transparency, temperature, water velocity
responses: pH, electrical conductivity, dissolved oxygen, ammonia, nitrates+nitrites, total N, total P, chlorophyll-a, bacteria: abundance of colony forming units
notes: interested in the impact of innundation on bacterial community, specifically the abudnacne of CFUs (colony forming units), unclear whether water quality parameters were considered a predictor or a response, but they discussed variation in the parameters by site so I listed as response
connectivity_def: identified three groups through PCA: initial flood pulse (A), lower water level (B), later isolated flood pulse Â©
cc_notes: sampled five sites (some channel, some lake, selection and classification unclear) over seasonal changes in flow and then used PCA to distinguish three groups: initial flood pulse, low water level, and isolated flood pulses. They then analyzed differences between these three groups

title: water level as the key controlling regulator associated with nutrient and gross primary productivity changes in a large floodplain-lake system (lake poyang), china
site_size: 15 sites covering different parts of the lake
connectivity_metric: water level used to define seasonal periods with different connectivity characteristics
responses: water temperature, conductivity, total dissolved solids, oxidation-reduction potential, pH, dissolved total carbon, dissolved organic carbon, dissolved inorganic carbon, dissolved total nitrogen, nitrate nitrogen, ammonia nitrogen, phosphate, silicate, total nitorgen, total phosphorus, phytoplankton species composition, density, and biomass, chl-a
chlorophyll_response: increase (highest during the rising season, lowest during the falling period and dry season)
data_analysis_method: kruskal-wallis rank sum test, pariwise comparioson, non-parametric Mann-Kendall analysis, PRCA, pearson correlation coefficients
notes: NA
temporal_def: dry season, rising period, wet season, falling period
cc_notes: connectivity measure was water level, not days of surface water connection, but seemed to fit this category because the same sites were compare between time periods of different connectivity
include_exclude_reason: recorded response of chl-a to changes in water level in lake-floodplain system

title: consistent trophic patterns among fishes in lagoon and channel habitats of a tropical floodplain river: evidence from stable isotopes
responses: stable isotopes of food resources and fish
notes: Discusses differences between tropical and temparate systems which may be relevant to our analyssi/disussion. Does not report chlorophyl, but would be relevant for food web/fish analysis
cc_notes: sampled lagoons and main channel "during the falling-water period of the dry season (November-April) fromo 1999-2005)". BUT "most lagoon samples" were from a lagoon that is permenantly connected to the main channel throughout the year. Analysis compared lagoon to channel.
include_exclude: unsure, no if we require chl-a
include_exclude_reason: contains data for food web/fish, but not primary productivity

title: drought alters the biogeochemistry of boreal stream networks
responses: oxygen concentration, conecntrations of other solutes and gases, metabolism,
notes: Focuses on the impact of drought on water chemistry in high-latitude streams. Simulated drought by adding dam to a system. In a sense this relates to longitudinal connectivity, and the authors discusses lateral groundwater inputs in the discussion, but otherwise does not seem to address connectivity
cc_notes: inclusion/exclusion unclear - impact of drought on stream; no connectivity classification, but sampling sites selected by distance from dam
include_exclude_reason: I think no because not really about connectivity and does not address primary productivity; unsure, no if we require chl-a, also maybe no on the grounds of connectivity

title: effect of hydrological connectivity on the phosphorus buffering capacity of an urban floodplain
watershed: Lower Lobau, a floodplain of the Danube River
notes: focused on the impact of connectivity on phosphorus dynamics
connectivity_def: connectivity defined as "the average number of days per year where a surface water connection with the main channel of the Danube is established"
cc_notes: used quantiative metric to define habitat categories; connectivity defined as average number of days per year where surface water connection is established; defined six water body types (large frequencly connected, large rarely connect, small and isolated, flowing water boidies, temporary frequenly connected, temporary rarely connected. Analysis compared water body types and also sediment types
include_exclude: unsure, no if we require chl-a

title: evaluating controls on the formation and reservoir architecture of niagaran pinnacle reefs (silurian) in the michigan basin; a sequence stratigraphic approach

title: management options for restoring estuarine dynamics and implications for ecosystems: a quantitative approach for the southwest delta in the netherlands
water_body_size: not stated, but discharge rates for different regions are provided
year: NA (no sampling occurred, simulation period was 2006-2009)
responses: flow rate, salinity, total nitrogen, chlorophyll-a, habitat area
notes: Focuses on a highly modified and managed system, which is unique among the other papers I have read so far. Maybe relevant to thinking about CA systems. Note: authors state that chlorophyll-a is not well reproduced by the model and therefore they only looked at relative changes, not absolute values. Not sure if we want to include because does not include measured chlorophyll values, just simulated.
cc_notes: exclude because only simulated data. Modeled changes in the Netherlans Delta Words under different managemetn scenarios. Increases or decreases in connectivity under different management scenarios were defined by "expert opinion", g seemed like the closest category fit

title: variations in dissolved greenhouse gases (co2, ch4, n2o) in the congo river network overwhelmingly driven by fluvial-wetland connectivity
site_size: multiple expeditions with varying coverage areas; areas not stated
water_body_size: drainage basin: 3.7x10^6km2; river length: 4400km; estimated flooded cover of 360,000km^2; total surface area: 1,760,000km^2
seasons: March-December, but not necessarily in the same years or sites
connectivity_process: floodplain innundation during high water times
connectivity_metric: percent flooded dense forest on catchment
predictors: stream order, distance from tributary, percent cover of flooded forest
responses: partial pressure or conenctration of various gases: CO2, O2, CH4, N2O; conductivity, temperature, stable isotopes, pH, POC, PN,
notes: not focused on chl-a response, but did collect chl-a data; focused on dynamics of dissolved greenhouse gases; looked at the influence of river-wetland connection on dissolved greenhouse gases, as well as longitudinial patters between various sites and tributaries on the Congo River
connectivity_def: whether stream was drained or did not drain from the Cuvette Centrale Congolaise wetland; percent of the catchement that was flooded forest
cc_notes: studied impact of wetland/floodplain connectivity on concentrations of dissolved greenhouse gases; did sample over multiple seasons, but analysis did not seem to compare seasonal changes in relation to connectiviyt; did sample of multiple years, but the sample did not seem to be repeated across years

title: abundance and biomass responses of microbial food web components to hydrology and environmental gradients within a floodplain of the river danube Rit
predictors: connectivity phase, pH, EC, DO, water temperature, water depth, ammonium, nitrates, nitrites, phosphorus
responses: heterotrophic nanoflagellates (predators), bacterioplankton (prey), chl-a (total phytoplankton), nanophytoplankton
food_web: decrease in bacteria from isolation to flood, but no change in heterotrophic nanoflagellates,  flood had lower nanophytoplankton than isolation or flow
data_analysis_method: PCA and Parallel Analysis to determine significant predictors,  scores then used in hierarchical multiple regression to compare across connectivity phases
notes: Very relevant to our work, although no fish; quantitative effects of connectivity (hydrological) phases on chl-a with mean, sds, n in Table 1
connectivity_def: isolation (<1.67 m; lentic conditions), flow pulse (> 1.67 m rising and falling limb of the hydrograph; semilotic or lotic conditions),  flood pulse (>3 m; lotic conditions)
cc_notes: river level averaged for 1 week prior to sampling and compared to threshold levels to determine surface connection between floodplain and river
include_exclude_reason: include due to all 3 criteria met

repeats_code: yes? (but seasons not explicitly discussed, only in terms of measured water levels and sampling every 3 months)
title: floods increase similarity among aquatic habitats in river-floodplain systems
predictors: suspended matter, conductivity, water temperature, water depth, pH
data_analysis_method: spatial CV of responses vs. water level
notes: Neotropical (Brazil, Venezuela), and temperate (Illinois, Mississippi, and Danube) locations for literature review (see Table 1); Amazon (Brazil) for empirical study.  Data entries here are based on empirical study.  Mostly opinion paper with main point: floods reduce spatial variability of chl-a across connected habitats (e.g., river, floodplain, lake); they called this phenomenon flood homogenization or reduction in beta diversity) as hydrology drives production while during low water levels biology drives localized dynamics within each habitat. Exclude from quantitative meta-analysis
temporal_def: sampled Lake Batata every 3 mo over 8 years across different water levels  and high vs. low years across 10 lakes in same watershed with Trombetas river connection
regulated: unsure (although a 2019 article I found online discusses 351 dams proposed for the Amazon basin!)
connectivity_def: coefficient of variation (CV) in limnological data obtained in (i) three sampling stations at a single lake (Lake Batata) every three months during 8 years and (ii) in ten lakes and two sampling sites of Trombetas River obtained in a single year at the high and low water levels.
cc_notes: laterally-connected water bodies fed by hyporheic water show lower coherence (e.g., in nutrient concentrations)
include_exclude_reason: include due to all 3 criteria met

title: hydrological pulse regulating the bacterial heterotrophic metabolism between amazonian mainstems and floodplain lakes
watershed: Cabaliana, Janauaca, Miratuba,  Canaçari, and Curuai floodplains, Amazon
responses: Tot-P, pH, turbidity,  13C and 15N of the particulate organic carbon(POC), conductivity, O2, chl-a, bacterial abundance, DOC
chlorophyll_response: chl-a range was similar in mainstem rivers in HW and LW and increased in floodplain lakes in LW.
food_web: bacterial production was greater in floodplain lakes than in mainstem in low water  and generally higher in low water than in high water
notes: 3-6 subsurface samples per mainstem station and 6-7 subsurface samples per floodplain lake; doesn't have exact sample sizes; main focus is bacterial response
temporal_def: sampled only 1 time each high and low water
connectivity_def: high vs. low water in mainstem and floodplain lakes
cc_notes: range of 3-6 m difference between high and low water
include_exclude_reason: include due to all 3 criteria met

title: seasonal variations in food web dynamics of floodplain lakes with contrasting hydrological connectivity in the southern gulf of mexico
latitude: 17.5919 N (Lake Canitzan), 17.7544 N (Lake Nueva Esperanza), 18.3583 N (Lake San Pedrito), 18.4059 N (Lake San Isidro)
longitude: - 91.3919 W (Lake Canitzan), - 91.8010 W (Lake Nueva Esperanza), - 92.5956 W (San Pedrito), - 92.4747 W (San Isidro)
seasons: dry, early rainy, and late rainy seasons
responses: water temperature, specific conductivity, salinity, dissolved oxygen (DO, concentration and saturation), pH, water transparency, nitrate-nitrogen, phosphorus, POM, turbidity, chl-a, stable isotopes of autochthonous aquatic macrophytes and phytoplankton and allocthonous (terrestrial) vegetation
chlorophyll_response: chl-a 18 times higher in isolated vs. connected lakes, and did not vary by season; chl-a related to TP in connected lakes, and to turbidity in isolated lakes
food_web: fish at different trophic levels; 4-7 week lag between 1st rain event and assumed diet incorporation into sampled fish (although says can happen within a few days in the tropics)
data_analysis_method: stable isotope-based community metrics with PERMANOVA to see differences across connected vs. isolated lakes and through 3 seasons, and Bayesian mixing models of fish assemblages across sites and seasons
notes: looked at differences in water quality  parameters and chl-a by connected vs. isolated lake status; quantitative effects of connectivity (hydrological) phases on chl-a with mean, sds  in Table 1
temporal_def:
sampled during dry (February–April), early-rainy season(June–July) and late-rainy (beginning of ‘‘nortes’’)
season (October) of 2015
connectivity_def: lake is connected (Lakes Canitzan and Nueva Esperanza) vs. isolated (Lakes San Pedrito and San Isidro) from river
cc_notes: also noted one of the lakes was more connected than other permanently-connected lakes due to number of channel connections to river and channel width
include_exclude_reason: include due to all 3 criteria met

title: spatial variability of chlorophyll-a and abiotic variables in a river-floodplain system during different hydrological phases
seasons: High (>3.40 m) and low (<3.40 m) water phases and extreme high (> 5 m) water phases
predictors: water level, depth:euphotic zone ratio, conductivity, water temperature, transparency, pH, conductivity, water current velocity, DO, turbidity, NO3
chlorophyll_response: water level, Zd:Zeu (inverse correlation) and conductivity (direct correlation) significantly explained Chl-a concentrations. Highest chl at low water
data_analysis_method: Nested ANOVA with hydrologic phase nested in site for differences in chl with multiple regression, and spatial CV for chl among sites
notes: in floodplains, Dilution processes and the decrease of water residence time negatively affect phytoplankton development; has mean differences in chlorophyll by high and low water phases
connectivity_def: lake is connected (Mini Lake) or isolated during extreme drought (Irupe Lake; i.e., when not in extreme drought Irupe Lake is also connected - however this did not happen during sampling); distinguish between potomophase for extreme-high water and ordinary high water vs. limnophase for low water
cc_notes:
High (>3.40 m) and low (<3.40 m) water phases occurring with interannual variability and extreme high ([5 m)
and low (<2.62 m) water phases are observed with variable frequency (extreme low not observed during their study).
include_exclude_reason: include due to all 3 criteria met

title: assessing the potential health risk of cyanobacteria and cyanotoxins in lake naivasha kenya
predictors: rainfall, evaporation, lake level, pH, conductivity, resistivity, temperature, salinity, total dissolved solids, DO
chlorophyll_response: increase in hypereutrophic events (chl-a > 50 ug/L) since late 1970s; cyanobacterial bloom during Sept 2010-March 2011 (same as months of study) with a peak in chl-a and cyanobacterium species in wet season
data_analysis_method: 2-way ANOVA to assess chl differences between months and lake basins
notes: Said that when chl-a is greater than 10 ug/L consistently, a lake is classified as eutrophic; also that high N/P ratios encourage cyanobacterial dominance; literature search for chl-a levels from 1970s to 2010
temporal_def: sampled weekly during wet season, every 2 weeks during dry season
connectivity_def: nutrient runoff from land to lake (so NA)
include_exclude_reason: No connectivity except for nutrient runoff into lakes and changes in lake levels due to rainfall

title: the effects of river floodwaters on floodplain wetland water quality and diatom assemblages
watershed: Jackson Bottom Wetlands Preserve, Tulatin River, Oregon
seasons: warm and dry summer, cool and wet winters (most rain Nov-Mar)
connectivity_metric: surface connectivity between river and floodplain, wetland water depth
predictors: conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH, water level, turbidity, temperature

data_analysis_method: Bray-Curtis and Sorensen's similarity indices for diatom assemblages

title: landscape ecology: a framework for integrating pattern and process in river corridors
watershed: Val Roseg, a glacial floodplain in the Swiss Alps; Fiume Tagliamento, an island-braided Italian River in the Alps; and Alluvial Zone National Park on the  Danube
site_size:
2.6 km long and up to 510 m
wide (Val Roseg); 172 km long river with 2 km floodplain (Fiume Tagliamento); 5.2 km2 floodplain (AZNP)
connectivity_metric: relative proportion (%) of the channel network length having an upstream surface connection with the main river channel (for Swiss Alps glacier-fed channel)
responses: primary productivity level (low, med, high), DOC: POC ratio

title: hydrologic pulsing promotes spatial connectivity and food web subsidies in a subtropical coastal ecosystem

cc_notes: The lagoon has a narrow outlet to the sea that is blocked from 126 February/March to August/September each year by sand dunes until freshwater inflows, usually from winter rainfall, establish a connection. If the seasonal connection with the sea is not established naturally, earth-moving machinery is used to construct an outlet channel (200 m long, 129 40 m wide, 1.5 m deep) during late winter (August-September). Note that measurements are made over time (rather than only before/after flood, so I put (e) for connectivity_measure but maybe that isn't right?

title: correlates of zooplankton beta diversity in tropical lake systems
watershed:
5 regions in Brazil: 24 lakes in Trombetas River
floodplain (Amazonian region, Northern Brazil), 20 lakes in the
Upper Parana´ River floodplain (Southern Brazil), 32 lakes in the
Middle Araguaia River floodplain (Central Brazil), 21 coastal lakes
and ponds located in the Restinga de Jurubatiba National Park
(Macae´, Southeast Brazil) and 23 lakes and ponds in the
Amazonian upland region (Caraja´s)
predictors:
TN, TP, pH, dissolved oxygen, conductivity, environmental heterogeneity,
spatial extent, hydrological connectivity (isolated vs.
floodplain lakes), seasonality (wet season or high water period vs.
dry season or low water period), disturbance (periodic dry-outs)
and productivity (mean chlorophyll-a concentration)
chlorophyll_response: NA (chl-a only reported on related to zooplankton beta diversity)
food_web: zooplankton beta diversity declined in regions with connected lakes (vs. with isolated lakes) but alpha diversity may be lower; no statistical relationship between chl-a concentration and zooplankton beta diversity
data_analysis_method: PERMDISP for environmental heterogeneity and spatial extent; LMMs for modeling beta diversity as function of predictors
notes: Not useful for connectivity effects on chl-a but provides info on chl-a effects on zooplankton diversity.

connectivity_def: permanently connected to river, temporarily connected to river, permanently isolated, or temporary ponds that dry up seasonally (latter 2 categories are not connected to the river)

notes: Flood events led dilution in nutrients/chlorophyll, followed by intense decomposition (flooded vegetation) when environments interconnected. During low connectivity, precipitation influenced events. |High water = high CO2, low O2, low phytoplankton
connectivity_def: water level = mean 14 days water level; used months to represent high vs low water level

title: spatial heterogeneity in trophic status of shallow lakes on the boreal plain: influence of hydrologic setting
connectivity_process: land-to-lake: saturated overland flow, lake-to-lake: streamflow, groundwater: Ca+Mg variation
connectivity_metric: land-lake: surface overland flow, lake-lake: stream connections, groundwater: groundwater flow path length
predictors: connectivity (surface-lake, lake-lake, groundwater), Ca-Mg (flow path length), % wetland
chlorophyll_response: increase with flow path length, decrease with % wetland, increase with lake connectivity
notes: boreal lakes - are these relevant?
connectivity_def:
land-lake: % wetland in contributing area (using soil moisture, satellite imagery, buffering area), lake-lake: isolated
(no stream connections), outflow (only outflowing stream),
and flow through (both inflowing and outflowing streams) (based on DEM, classifications by Strahler order, modified, and lake connectivity index - Martin and Sorano), groundwater: Ca + Mg, where higher values indicate higher flow path length,  absorbing more P

title: assessing the effects of lateral hydrological connectivity alteration on freshwater ecosystems: a meta-analysis
notes: NA

title: the performance of ecological cage aquaculture of pejerrey odontesthes bonariensis in pampean lakes under two different hydrological scenarios
responses: water temperature, conductivity, pH, depth, transparency, hourly rainfall, phosphorus, dissolved nutrients, chlorophyll-a, phosophorus, nitrite, ammonia nitrogen

notes: Difference in species comp phyto (Cyanobacteria in connected lake); More cladocerans in disconnected

title: echoes of a flood pulse: short-term effects of record flooding of the illinois river on floodplain lakes under ecological restoration
responses: water temperature, dissolved oxygen, pH, conductivity, turbidity, total depth, secchi depth, chla, TSS, nitrate, soluble reactive phosphorus, total ammonia, total phosphorus, total nitrogen, pelagic bacterial community composition, zooplankton; aquatic vegetation; fishes; waterbirds
notes: NA

title: ecosystem metabolism and nutrient dynamics in the main channel and backwaters of the upper mississippi river
predictors: total daily surface irradiance, mean daily water temperature, TN, TP, chlorophyll,  discharge
responses: dissolved oxygen, rates of ecosystem metabolism
primary_productivity_metric: aquatic GPP, aquatic respiration, aquatic net ecosystem production (NEP)
notes: backwater had greater GPP and R than main channel, but NEP>0 more common in main channel. Chlorophyll correlated with NEP, R, GPP in models. Chlorophyll is not the response variable here.
temporal_def: model results by day of year
connectivity_def: main channel, backwater, backwater could be low connectivity or high connectivity depending on number of connections to main channel
cc_notes: not about chlorophyll a but instead of primary production, respiration, NEP

title: effects of hydrologic connectivity on water chemistry, soils, and vegetation structure and function in an intermontane depressional wetland landscape
predictors: Type of wetland (ground water discharge vs. surface water discharge, connected vs isolated), precipitation, geomorphology
responses: Species richness, species evenness, net primary productivity, vegetation species comp
data_analysis_method: DCA for vegetation species composition and relationships with abiotic measurements
notes: Not relevant to our system
cc_notes: depressional wetlands; no chla measured; 2 years of data (Apr-Sep)

title: hydrologic habitat preferences of select southeastern usa fishes resilient to river ecosystem fragmentation
watershed: Lake Logan Martin (part of Coosa River), Choccolocco Creek
notes: wholly focused on fish. lentic vs lotic - does this count as connectivity?More "hydrologic habitats." Really don't discuss connectivity in this paper so I put "N" for connectivity but did put lentic v lotic as a classification for the coding exercise.  did not separate out fish analyses since not phyto.
cc_notes: "large southeastern USA impoundment and its largest unregulated lotic tributary"; repeats_code Y for looking at lentic vs lotic (5 years) but not for drought vs no drought (only 1 drought year); don't really frame lentic vs lotic in terms of connectivity

title: hydrological control of system characteristics of floodplain lakes
connectivity_metric: months connection; water age; connected/disconnected/flooding (not defined)
predictors: connectivity (water age, floodplain discharge, hydrological connectivity month), Phosphate, restoration before/after
responses: chlorophyll, PIM, bacteria, phosphate, POC, C:N ratio, 13C isotope values of POC , bacteria
chlorophyll_response: greater at intermediate connectedness (until phosphate limited, or too high flows); decreased by high macrophyte densities, increase with bacteria, phosphate
notes: this is a review of studies
connectivity_def:
duration of surface water connectivity between river and its backwaters in  months per year; water age: Here,
age is defined as how long the water has
been contained in the water body system, up to any
position within the system, at any point in time.
cc_notes: this paper discusses several studies (kind of review)

title: biogeochemistry of carbon in the amazonian floodplains over a 2000-km reach: insights from a process-based model
responses: carbon flux, proportion of aquatic carbon flux, Carbon13 isotopic signature, Nitrate, pH, O2, DON, DOC/DON, fumic to humic acid ratio, outgassing rates of CH4, , mineralization rate of DOM, moreâ€¦
notes: There is a lot I don't understand in this paper. The main useful takeaway seems to be that flooded area and discharge affect the processes. During low waters, there is more aquatic photosynthesis, and depending on water stage (falling, low, rising), main source (terrestrial/aquatic) of carbonsequestraton will change.
cc_notes: season is relevant to connectivity but not sure they are really describing the annual cycle rather than comparing connectivity states
